Message.Title: romney to RAISE your taxes, lower his
Message.Msg: arrogance & greed are the only motivation he has. http://finance.yahoo.com/blogs/daily-ticker/romney-economic-plan-cut-taxes-rich-raise-them-160632248.html

I must be missing something. How have those tax cuts helped the wealthy to the extent you imply? They are still in a higher tax bracket plus they must pay the alternative minimum tax plus they don't qualify for many of the deductions those in the lower income bracket do. The biggest tax break, IMO, is that on capitol gains but all Americans are privy to that, aren't they? Or is it assumed that those in the lower income bracket cannot afford investments therefore that makes it unfair? In order to level the playing field perhaps capital gains should be paid at the same rate as income but not more like Obama wants. A while back I posted this on my FB page (I have tried like hell not to get political on my page but sometimes I can't help myself). I didn't get a very big response but I didn't expect to. One person said, ouch that makes my head hurt. I forget what the few others said: Did you know the current Tax Code is 7500 pages? That's 7500 pages of rules for filing your taxes. Our tax system is broken. Today I looked up what the "tax breaks for the wealthy" are. The second largest "tax break" is the deduction of mortgage interest. (Apparently you are considered "wealthy" if you can afford to own a home and it's considered an unfair tax break to those who don't since they can't take the deduction.) The #1 largest tax break is employer deduction of medical insurance to its employees. Doesn't that encourage companies to offer free health insurance to its employees? I'm thinking if that tax break is eliminated it will be one employee benefit you won't see much of anymore. Same with 401K plans (#4 on the list). #3 on this list is capitol gains (currently fixed tax rate of 15%). That means if you own a home, retire and downsize you currently pay 15% capital gains tax on the profit of the home you sold. It's on the table to raise that to 39.6% plus another 5.2% for some other tax. That's 44.8%. Ouch. Doesn't pay to downsize. Think real estate is hurting now? One last note, the "alternative minimum tax" is an extra tax paid by the wealthy (and some middle class) over and above the current tax bracket rates. This tax is to make sure the wealthy are paying their fair share and aren't getting over with the "tax breaks" mentioned above. So doesn't the bottom line "tax owned" balance out for "the wealthy"? Enlighten me.
Flat rate tax would be the fairest system 10% across the board NO deductions! It would be simple, easy and fair. . .
I can live with that but it would likely need to be more (like double - 20%) and it should include capitol gains. Why hasn't that been done?

Message.Title: Using More Craigslist ~ Less Ebay
Message.Msg: This is what Ebay wants and it's what Ebay gets!
The f-in tax code would go from 7200 pages to 1 page.
And the f'in tax forms would go from a book to one page.
It's too simple It would downsize the IRS by 75% and ruin the income tax business
LOL...

"One last note, the "alternative minimum tax" is an extra tax paid by the wealthy (and some middle class) over and above the current tax bracket rates." That is a common misunderstanding of the alternative minimum tax. It is paid INSTEAD of the regular rates. It can be paid at a lower rate but still be a higher tax because some deductions allowable against regular tax are not deductible against alternative minimum tax. But it is not an "add-on" tax. There is no proposal to raise the long term gain rate to 39.6 percent for the wealthy. Obama hasn't proposed it and it would not gain support of quite a few Democrats if he did. Your post is essentially a fear factor one not rooted in political realities. And what about this threat to lie down and stop working if your taxes get any higher. That is not what got a small business owner anywhere and such a retirement will simply leave the same business opportunity to someone else. Higher taxes could raise the cost of capital, but not the need for capital. There is plenty of capital around in this and other economies. Higher taxes are an inevitable PART of the kind of fiscal restraint the federal government will need to undertake someday even if it is imposed by outside lenders.
Being "IN" the business of taxes What do you think of a flat rate tax with no deductions?

You are either a regular taxpayer or an alternative taxpayer. You have to play the strategy that meets your situation. If your income is in a certain range (I don't know your state so I don't know your range) or you have lots of capital gains, you are an alternative taxpayer and you actually WANT to be in AMT. You would be messing up if you paid a higher regular tax. It is a version of flat tax that is a reality for millions of taxpayers, a few million anyway.
i see
wait...are you saying there's a choice in the matter and one doesn't have to pay the AMT way? I thought the AMT added back in some deductions before calculating the tax, who would choose that?

Message.Title: too many insider sales
Message.Msg: They probably know something we don't

You have to pay whichever tax calculation is higher. The choice you have is a planning one. If you are going to pay AMT every year there is no point in prepaying your property tax except when it is due and no point in paying up your state tax in December to get a deduction. Those taxes are not deductible for AMT. The same goes for employee business expenses which also are not deductible for AMT.

Property tax & state tax are due when they're due (unless you want to pay penalty & interest) and in most cases prop. tax comes right out mortgage escrow. Even if you don't pay those taxes on time it's going to catch up sooner or later and must come out of the AMT calculation. Same goes with business expenses. So, bottom line is it is an additional tax to the "rich".

The truly rich usually don't pay AMT. I am talking about incomes in seven figures. Unless they have capital gains, they usually don't pay AMT and they may not pay it even if they do have capital gains and qualifying dividends (which are treated like long term capital gains and taxed at preferential rates). The seven figure incomes are usually planned for as "regular taxpayers", not "alternative" ones, but it has to be determined case by case.

I wasn not talking about delaying the payment of taxes past the due date. People sometimes accelerate property tax and state income taxes forward to an earlier year to speed up the tax deductions, and I am saying that is usually useless if you are in AMT.
You're either upset you didn't get in the day before last earnings report, or unrealistic in your expectations. I think this is doing just fine right now.

Message.Title: romney creates jobs for OFF SHORE banker's
Message.Msg: But that’s not the only thing Romney’s returns might show. Reuters’ Sam Youngman reported on a related issue: His vast fortune is invested in dozens of funds linked to Bain Capital LLC, the powerhouse private equity firm he co-founded and led for 15 years. Several Bain funds have offshore connections and take advantage of tax breaks used only by the U.S. financial elite. His tax returns could shed light on how Romney and Bain use offshore strategies to avoid taxes, said Daniel Berman, a former U.S. Treasury deputy international tax counsel and now director of tax at Boston University’s graduate tax program. Bain funds in which Romney is invested are scattered from Delaware to the Cayman Islands and Bermuda, Ireland and Hong Kong, according to a Reuters analysis of securities filings. http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/political-animal/2012_01/romneys_offshore_accounts_draw034846.php
